Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Fellowships: 2015 Web Reasoning and Rule Systems Conference and 2015 Reasoning Web Summer School

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Semantic technologies, Linked Open Data, and knowledge representation formalisms such as the Web Ontology Language OWL are beginning to play increasingly important roles across a broad range of applications. There is an urgent need for the advanced training of graduate students to conduct research in this area and to prepare them for academic or industrial careers. Participation in premier research conferences in the area is an essential element of such training. This project will provide funds to subsidize the travel expenses of 6 students at U.S. universities to attend the 2015 Web Reasoning and Rules Systems conference, RR2015, and the 2015 Reasoning Web Summer School, which will be held July 31 - August 5 in Berlin, Germany. Broader impacts of the project include: Enhanced opportunities for training and mentoring of US-based graduate students in Semantic Web and related areas, broadening the participation of students from groups (women and minorities) that are currently under-represented in Computer Science in general, and Semantic Web in particular.

The Web Reasoning and Rule Systems conference series, established in 2007, and the annual Reasoning Web Summer School series, attract the leading researchers in the field of Web Reasoning, and offer a venue for presentation of the latest advances in the field. Covered topics include ontology modeling languages, e.g., RDF, OWL, and RIF, which enable the inference of implicit knowledge from knowledge that is explicitly encoded in the knowledge base. Web Reasoning and related fields focus on the design, analysis, and development of ontology languages, study of their theoretical properties, and the design and implementation of effective inference algorithms. The co-location of the conference and summer school provides for an excellent venue for the training of graduate students. In addition to attending the invited and contributed talks at the conference, and the summer school, the students will benefit from individualized mentoring by established researchers.

For further information see the project webpage: https://users.soe.ucsc.edu/~btencate/rr2015fellowships.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Semantic Web is based on the idea of describing the meaning—or semantics—of data on the Web using metadata (i.e., data that describes other data) in the form of ontologies [12]. Ontologies are represented using languages based on formal logic, and one of their key features is that they enable access to implicit knowledge through formal logical reasoning [14]. The computational realization of this is called automated reasoning, which thus enables intelligent information management methods for search, integration, browsing, organization, and reuse of information, and is thus a flexible method which provides added value for content management applications. We (and others) refer to this as Web Reasoning. The International Conference on Web Reasoning and Rule Systems is a major forum for discussion and dissemination of new results in this area, while the Reasoning Web series of annual summer schools is a prime educational event in this field.

The present grant enabled US-based students to travel to the RR/RW 2016 conference and summer school, which form key community event in the area of semantic web technologies and rule-based reasoning. The RR/RW conference and summer school provided a range of student-centric events such as the doctoral consortium and the mentoring lunch. The funding enabled students to partake in these events and to present their research. Secifically, the NSF-sponsored RR/RW student travel fellowships (administered through the University of California, Santa Cruz) helped 5 students to attend the RR 2016 conference and/or the RW 2016 summer school, including the joint RR/RW doctoral consortium. Most of these students would not have been able to attend without the support of the fellowship.

More broadly, beyond benefiting the education of the US-based students, and helping them shape their research, the project helped make RR/RW conference and summer school successful, foster international collaborations, and train a new generation of students to become succesful academics and/or professionals equipped with the fundamental tools needed to develop the future state-of-the-art in semantic information systems.
